verses.text: How lovely are your dwelling places, O LORD of hosts!
verses.comment: The psalmist expresses deep longing for God's sanctuary, reflecting both the literal temple in Jerusalem and, spiritually, the Church as the dwelling place of God. Early Christian interpretation often sees this as foreshadowing the unity and beauty of the Christian Church.

verses.text: My soul longs, yes, even faints, for the courts of the LORD; my heart and my flesh cry out for the living God.
verses.comment: The desire for God's presence points toward the ultimate fulfillment in Christ, through whom access to God is made perfect (cf. Hebrews 10:19-22). Note the union of flesh and spirit in seeking God, resonant with Catholic teaching on the sacramental unity of body and soul.

verses.text: Even the sparrow finds a home, and the swallow builds her nest for herself, where she may put her young—at your altars, O LORD of hosts, my King and my God.
verses.comment: God's care is for all His creatures, and the image of birds near the altar reflects both God's tenderness and the welcoming nature of His house. Some early Church Fathers saw in this a hint of all people being called to God's table.

verses.text: Blessed are those who dwell in your house; they are always praising you. Selah.
verses.comment: Dwelling in God's house is an image of both worship in the earthly temple and, in Catholic understanding, the enduring presence within the Communion of Saints and daily participation in the Eucharist.

verses.text: Blessed are those whose strength is in you, in whose heart are the highways to Zion.
verses.comment: The journey to Zion represents the spiritual pilgrimage of the Christian life, culminating in communion with God. Early Christian writers saw this as a type of the soul's ascent to God, and the ‘highways’ as sacraments leading us home.

verses.text: As they pass through the Valley of Baca, they make it a place of springs; the early rain also covers it with pools.
verses.comment: The Valley of Baca (Valley of Weeping) can be understood literally or as symbolic of trials on the way to God. The transformation into springs points to grace and renewal, often interpreted by the Fathers as baptismal imagery.

verses.text: They go from strength to strength; every one of them appears before God in Zion.
verses.comment: The journeying worshipers finally appear before God, foreshadowing the ultimate vision of God in heaven (cf. Revelation 21:2-3). For Catholics, the pilgrimage motif recalls both individual sanctification and the centrality of communal worship and tradition.

verses.text: O LORD God of hosts, hear my prayer; give ear, O God of Jacob. Selah.
verses.comment: The psalmist's appeal to God as ‘God of Jacob’ connects personal prayer to the covenant and community of faith. The name also invokes God's faithfulness to His people.

verses.text: Look upon our shield, O God; regard the face of your anointed.
verses.comment: The word 'anointed' (Hebrew: Messiah, Greek: Christos) hints at both Davidic kingship and ultimately points prophetically to Christ. The plea to look upon the anointed’s face suggests intercession, an important theme in Catholic theology.

verses.text: For a day in your courts is better than a thousand elsewhere. I would rather stand at the threshold of the house of my God than dwell in the tents of wickedness.
verses.comment: The psalmist’s delight in God’s presence highlights the surpassing worth of worship, echoing the Catholic appreciation for the Mass as foretaste of heaven itself.

verses.text: For the LORD God is a sun and shield; the LORD gives grace and glory; no good thing does he withhold from those who walk uprightly.
verses.comment: ‘Sun and shield’ combine God’s illuminating presence and protection. The mention of grace and glory is significant theologically: the grace that sanctifies and the glory that awaits, both central in Catholic theology (cf. 2 Peter 1:3-4).

verses.text: O LORD of hosts, blessed is the man who trusts in you!
verses.comment: This closing summarizes the theme: trust in God leads to true blessing. This trust, for Catholics, is lived both individually and communally in the life of the Church, including faith in God’s providence and the sacraments.
